IP2026033_syn_2:
HISTORY: [REDACTED] a delayed pneumothorax two weeks following LLL valve placement. Despite chest tube thoracostomy, the lung failed to fully re-expand, suggesting a valvular mechanism or persistent parenchymal leak.
PROCEDURE: The patient was intubated. Bronchoscopic inspection revealed four Zephyr valves seated in the LLL. To facilitate lung re-expansion, the decision was made to retrieve the devices. All four valves were successfully extracted without complication. Inspection of the bronchial mucosa showed expected post-implantation inflammatory changes but no purulence.
CONCLUSION: Successful retrieval of LLL valves. Post-procedure imaging demonstrates improved aeration of the left lower lobe.

IP2026033:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with removal of endobronchial valves, left lower lobe, for delayed post-BLVR pneumothorax.
Patient: [REDACTED], 59-year-old female with severe emphysema status post LLL BLVR 2 weeks prior.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (7.5 mm ETT).
Indication: Recurrent symptomatic left pneumothorax with persistent air leak and incomplete lung expansion despite appropriately positioned chest tube following recent LLL BLVR.
Background: The patient underwent LLL BLVR with four valves 14 days ago. She was discharged after an uncomplicated initial hospital course. She re-presented with pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea; CXR showed a moderate left pneumothorax, and a chest tube was placed. After several days on suction, there was persistent air leak and failure of the LLL to re-expand.
Procedure details: Under general anesthesia, a therapeutic bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT. The left bronchial tree was inspected. Four Zephyr valves were visualized in the basilar and superior segmental bronchi of the LLL. Given the persistent air leak, all four valves were removed sequentially using valve retrieval forceps. Each valve was collapsed and withdrawn through the scope without difficulty. The underlying bronchi demonstrated mild inflammatory changes but no purulence.
Complications: No significant bleeding. Oxygenation and hemodynamics remained stable. Post-procedure CXR showed improved LLL expansion with the chest tube in place and no increase in pneumothorax size.
Disposition: Returned to telemetry floor with chest tube to -20 cm H2O suction.
Plan: Daily chest radiographs; trial of water seal once air leak decreases; chest tube removal when lung fully expanded. No further BLVR planned for the LLL.
